abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Municipal Development
            Project (MDP) of Mozambique were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            substantial, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: (i) the design
            of a project and in particular of a pilot program should be
            kept simple and within the capacity of the staff and
            agencies responsible for its implementation. In this case
            the project and the pilot were both too complex; (ii) the
            implementation must be flexible to adapt to changes in the
            environment - in this case the design of the Municipal Grant
            Fund (MGF) was frequently adjusted to reflect lessons
            learned which resulted in successfully testing a transfer
            system that enabled local staff to design and implement
            small projects within a 12 month cycle; (iii) the initial
            mechanism to transfer of funds was complex because of an
            unreliable treasury system at the time of the project's
            design. However, since the current treasury system is well
            established, future transfers to the municipalities should
            be via the intergovernmental transfer system and not using
            the mechanism tested in the pilot; (iv) the MGF pilot
            developed in the third cycle a mechanism which included a
            provision that contracts could only be signed when all
            required funding was in place. This modification addressed
            the counterpart funding problem and reduced the time to
            completion dramatically; (v) increased involvement of the
            staff in the implementing agencies in management of the
            project would have helped to increase the local capacity
            more than by utilizing outside implementing units for the
            central and municipal governments; and (vi) the MGF had a
            complex implementation framework involving too many decision
            makers and which minimized the importance of local
            ownership. If decentralized systems are to be successful,
            they must have the active support and involvement of the
            elected officials and staff from the local governments;
            (vii) the lessons from the MDP and other projects show that
            political leadership and commitment from the
            mayors/presidents is a pre-condition for a successful
            project design and management since the mayor has much
            greater ownership and direct responsibility and
            accountability; (viii) the involvement of WBI in the
            implementation of component 2 was the major reason for the
            improvement in that component and for the eventual impact of
            the training program; (ix) The outcome of the MDP shows that
            better coordinated efforts from GOM and partners for
            capacity development is important and necessary; and (x) it
            is essential for the team leaders for the government and
            Bank project teams to develop a strong working relationship
            built on effective communication to ensure the efforts of
            both organizations are working toward the same objective.

8357746.trustfund:
TF025759-PHRD-URBAN ENVIRON. &
            MUNICIPAL MGMT.,TF037557-MOZAMBIQUE - URBAN DEVELOPMENT PROJECT,TF039820-MOZAMBIQUE - MUNICIPAL
            DEVELOPMENT PROJECT

repnme.cdata!:
Mozambique - Municipal Development Project
            - amendment to Credit Agreement

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Project are to
            assist the Government in operationalizing the legal, and
            institutional framework for municipal governance, developing
            a sustainable training and technical assistance system, and
            increase the capacity of municipal officials and personnel,
            and, in establishing an operating mechanism for providing
            grants to municipalities, through a pilot program in five
            cities to finance capital investments for municipal capacity
            building, and infrastructure.  Although the overall
            development objective remains realistic and achievable,
            there are however a number of steps the Government needs to
            take, to restructure the project, and ensure these
            objectives are attained. This proposed amendment would: a)
            increase the number of cities named in the project
            development objective, and included in Component 3 -
            Municipal Grants - from five to eight for the remainder of
            the project; and b) specifically include provisions under
            Component 4 - Project Management and Technical Assistance -
            for consultancies to evaluate the pilot, and provide
            recommendations to the Government for a future program that
            would include all 33 municipalities. The proposed amendment
            would incur no additional cost, yet it would enable a more
            thorough evaluation of the pilot, that would be important to
            scale-up the learning and benefits from the project as a
            whole in the future. The increased number of municipalities
            would scale-up immediate project impact for the design of a
            future set of mechanisms for the Government, thus support
            municipal development which depends crucially on careful
            analysis of the pilot and lessons learned. The proposed
            credit amendment complies with the Articles of Agreement of
            the Association, and it is recommended for approval.

5077407.trustfund:
TF039820-MOZAMBIQUE - MUNICIPAL
            DEVELOPMENT PROJECT,TF037557-MOZAMBIQUE - URBAN DEVELOPMENT PROJECT,TF025759-PHRD-URBAN ENVIRON. &
            MUNICIPAL MGMT.
5077407.majtheme: Public sector governance,Urban development,Rule of law

abstracts.cdata!:
The Municipal Development Project will
            strengthen the capacity of municipal governments in the
            areas of management, finance, and the provision of
            infrastructure services. It will assist the Government in
            the operation of legal, institutional, and fiscal
            frameworks, providing training to municipal officials, and
            staff, and, will pilot a municipal grants mechanism, to
            finance investments, laying the foundation for an
            inter-governmental fiscal system. Specifically, the
            components will: 1) provide technical assistance (TA) to the
            Ministry of State Administration, for the drafting of legal
            instruments, and the preparation of studies, manuals, and
            other materials needed to establish the legal, and policy
            framework for municipal development; 2) provide in-service
            training to elected, and appointed municipal officials, and
            staff, and, will also develop pre-service training, and
            provide TA to improve processes. The training will support
            municipal government systems, and public administration,
            emphasizing technical skills in municipal finance, and
            infrastructure delivery services; 3) provide municipalities
            with financial resources, through municipal grants, to
            implement civil works, supply equipment, provide consulting
            services, and enable municipalities to build the capacity to
            manage, and implement investments; and, 4) provide project
            management, and TA, including support for municipal
            engineering, procurement, contract management, and,
            supervisory, and financial aspects.

439776.trustfund:
TF025759-PHRD-URBAN ENVIRON. &

repnme.cdata!:
Mozambique - Municipal Development Project
            : environmental impact assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The municipal Development Project is
            expected to improve the environmental conditions in urban
            areas through the successful implementation of civil works
            programs in parallel with dynamic awareness campaigns
            targeting user communities. During the first phase of the
            civil works program, the five municipalities (Beira,
            Quelimane, Nampula, Pemba, and Maputo) will be limiting
            their works to surface water drainage, sewerage and
            sanitation, markets, waste disposal, and rehabilitation of
            pavements and footpaths. 1) During construction, storage or
            cement mixing sites will be located so that they do not
            contaminate local water resources. Awareness campaigns
            involving local communities will be promoted to keep
            drainage channels clean and free of debris. 2) Measures will
            be taken to ensure sanitary conditions are maintained at the
            new markets. 3) Contractual obligations of the contractors
            must include clauses regarding environmental protection,
            especially regarding post-construction site-cleaning.
            Latrines should not be constructed close to ground and
            surface water sources to avoid contamination. 4) Local
            population will be discouraged from using footpaths as
            latrines, and adequate drainage will be provided to preclude
            possible flooding and erosion. 5) Skips equipped with
            tight-ftting lids for waste disposal will be constructed to
            prevent foraging and breeding by pest species.
